Pulmonary Effects of Sulfur Dioxide Exposure in the Syrian Hamster
I. Combined With Viral Respiratory Disease 1. P. Goldring, PhD; P. Cooper, MD; I. M. Ratner, MD; and L. Greenburg, MD, PhD, New York
1
ALTHOUGH the evidence that air pollu- pheric inhalants of animals that have a re- tion contributes to the pathogenesis of chronic respiratory disease is significant,1 there has been no direct cause and effect demonstration in the assessment of this complex health problem.
Among the many gaseous contaminants of the atmosphere which may contribute to the health hazard, sulfur dioxide (SO2) has been most frequently incriminated. In 1960 it was estimated that 21 million tons of SO2 were released yearly into the atmos- phere of the United States.2
A summary of the biologie effects of SO2 in animals presented by Stokinger in 19623 indicated the following: (1) animal species differ considerably in their susceptibility to SO24; (2) age differences exist, with young animals being more susceptible than older animals; and (3) the survival period of ani- mals chronically exposed to low concentra- tions of SO2 is much lower than in control animals.5
. Prolonged exposure to SO, was reported to produce histopathological changes in the lungs, kidneys, liver, and myocardium of rabbits,6 and pulmonary fibrosis attributed to SO2 was found in awine exposed to the gas.T
The idea that exposure to noxious atmos-
Submitted for publication March 10, 1967; ac- cepted March 17.
From the departments of surgery (Drs. Goldring and Cooper), pathology (Dr. Ratner), and preventive medicine and community health (Dr. Greenburg), Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Department of Surgery, Veterans Administration Hospital (Dr. Cooper); and Department of Pathology, Jocobi Hos- pital (Dr. Ratner), New York.
Reprint requests to Department of Surgery, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1800 Morris Park Ave, New York 10461 (Dr. Goldring).
spiratory disease might lead to severe pul- monary pathology has been investigated to some extent. It has been demonstrated that mice co-challenged with influenza virus and aerosols of hydrocarbons develop squamous metaplasia.8 Attempts to produce tumors or pulmonary lesions in rats similarly chal- lenged with influenza virus and zinc or lead chromate injected intratracheally into the lungs have been unsuccessful."
Despite the fact that SO2 in serious air pollution episodes is usually implicated as a major factor in irritation of the lungs and even death, information is very limited as to the sequential histopathological effects which SO2 may produce on the tracheobron- chial tree and pulmonary parenchyma in laboratory animals exposed to this agent for long periods of time, Studies have not been conducted on the combined effects of SOg and respiratory tract disease in laboratory animals.
The present investigation was designed to study the sequential histopathological changes which might occur in the trachea and lungs of animals subjected to daily ex- posures of SOg, and to determine any addi- tive effect in the histopathology which might develop in animals previously challenged. with a respiratory virus. It was our hope that such a study might furnish some clues to the respiratory problems experienced by humans with respiratory ailments exposed to air pollution episodes.
Materials and Methods
Exposure Chamber .- The chamber employed by us has been described by Leuchtenberger et
Arch Environ Health-Vol 15, Aug 1967

paragraphs.content: Pulmonary Effects of Sulfur Dioxide Exposure in the Syrian Hamster
I. Combined With Viral Respiratory Disease 1. P. Goldring, PhD; P. Cooper, MD; I. M. Ratner, MD; and L. Greenburg, MD, PhD, New York

ALTHOUGH the evidence that air pollu- pheric inhalants of animals that have a re- tion contributes to the pathogenesis of chronic respiratory disease is significant,1 there has been no direct cause and effect demonstration in the assessment of this complex health problem.

Among the many gaseous contaminants of the atmosphere which may contribute to the health hazard, sulfur dioxide (SO2) has been most frequently incriminated. In 1960 it was estimated that 21 million tons of SO2 were released yearly into the atmos- phere of the United States.2

A summary of the biologie effects of SO2 in animals presented by Stokinger in 19623 indicated the following: (1) animal species differ considerably in their susceptibility to SO24; (2) age differences exist, with young animals being more susceptible than older animals; and (3) the survival period of ani- mals chronically exposed to low concentra- tions of SO2 is much lower than in control animals.5

. Prolonged exposure to SO, was reported to produce histopathological changes in the lungs, kidneys, liver, and myocardium of rabbits,6 and pulmonary fibrosis attributed to SO2 was found in awine exposed to the gas.T
The idea that exposure to noxious atmos-

spiratory disease might lead to severe pul- monary pathology has been investigated to some extent. It has been demonstrated that mice co-challenged with influenza virus and aerosols of hydrocarbons develop squamous metaplasia.8 Attempts to produce tumors or pulmonary lesions in rats similarly chal- lenged with influenza virus and zinc or lead chromate injected intratracheally into the lungs have been unsuccessful."

Despite the fact that SO2 in serious air pollution episodes is usually implicated as a major factor in irritation of the lungs and even death, information is very limited as to the sequential histopathological effects which SO2 may produce on the tracheobron- chial tree and pulmonary parenchyma in laboratory animals exposed to this agent for long periods of time, Studies have not been conducted on the combined effects of SOg and respiratory tract disease in laboratory animals.

The present investigation was designed to study the sequential histopathological changes which might occur in the trachea and lungs of animals subjected to daily ex- posures of SOg, and to determine any addi- tive effect in the histopathology which might develop in animals previously challenged. with a respiratory virus. It was our hope that such a study might furnish some clues to the respiratory problems experienced by humans with respiratory ailments exposed to air pollution episodes.
